title: Trump says Starmer and Macron `haven´t done anything´...
body:
Donald Trump has said Sir Keir Starmer and Emmanuel Macron "haven't done anything" to end the war in Ukraine.

The Prime Minister and the French president are due to visit Mr Trump separately in Washington next week amid a growing rift between between the US leader and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky.

The US president began negotiations on ending the conflict with Russia, but excluded Kyiv from the talks on Tuesday.

Mr Zelensky has "been in the meetings for three years and nothing got done," Mr Trump told a Fox News podcast.

"So I don't think he's very important to be at meetings to be honest with you," he added.

Asked about the upcoming visits from the UK and French leaders, he said: "They didn't do anything either (to end the war). The war's going on, no meetings with Russia, no nothing.

"They haven't done anything. Macron is a friend of mine, and I've met with the Prime Minister and he's a very nice guy (but) nobody's done anything."

Sir Keir has faced pressure to take a firm line with Mr Trump on support for Ukraine when he visits.

On Friday, Liberal Democrat leader Sir Ed Davey accused Mr Trump of plotting a "stitch-up" with Russian President Vladimir Putin that "amounts to a betrayal of Ukraine" and urged the Prime Minister to speak "honestly and openly" with him.

Sir Ed added: "I think we're all astonished and deeply alarmed, and if the British Prime Minister doesn't reflect that, he's not reflecting the views of the British people."

But senior Cabinet minister Pat McFadden stressed the importance of maintaining a "good and constructive relationship" with the White House at a fringe event at the Scottish Labour conference in Glasgow on Friday.

He said: "I think the UK is potentially in a good position with this administration, if we handle it correctly.

Pat McFadden said the Government should not follow `every twist and turn of every comment´ made by Donald Trump, but focus on `what will actually happen´ (Victoria Jones/PA)

"Handling it correctly doesn't mean following every twist and turn of every comment, but is focusing on what will actually happen as well as what was said."

Sir Keir will have to walk a tricky line when he meets Mr Trump in Washington next week, balancing the UK's support for Ukraine with the need to keep the US onside.

That task appears to have been made harder in the past week by the growing rift between Mr Trump and Mr Zelensky, whom the US leader has described as a "dictator".

The Ukrainian president had claimed Mr Trump was living in a Russian "disinformation space", which led White House officials to accuse Mr Zelensky of "insulting" his counterpart.

The Americans also cancelled a planned joint press conference in Kyiv, in a sign of a deepening feud between the two countries.

Businessman Elon Musk, who is acting as an adviser on federal spending to Mr Trump, meanwhile suggested Mr Zelensky is running a "fraud machine feeding off the dead bodies of soldiers", suggesting limited appetite for continued American support for Ukraine.

Sir Keir Starmer has reiterated the UK´s support for Ukraine and Volodymyr Zelensky despite the apparent rift between the Ukrainian president and Donald Trump (Carl Court/PA)

However, Mr Trump's Ukraine envoy, retired general Keith Kellogg, praised Mr Zelensky on Friday as an "embattled and courageous leader of a nation at war" following what he described as "extensive and positive discussions" between the two men.

Sir Keir's visit to the White House will follow a meeting between Mr Trump and Emmanuel Macron on Monday, at which the French president has said he intends to tell his American counterpart not to "be weak" in the face of Mr Putin.

In an hour-long question-and-answer session on social media, Mr Macron said he would tell Mr Trump: "It's not you, it's not your trademark, it's not in your interest.

"How can you then be credible in the face of China if you're weak in the face of Putin?"

taxonomy_info.explanation: The article explicitly identifies Donald Trump as the US president and quotes him, confirming both his name and the description.

reasoning.presence_detection: The article explicitly mentions "Donald Trump" and refers to him as "Mr Trump" and "US president". These references match the target entity name and description (US President).
reasoning.statement_detection: Multiple direct quotes are attributed to him: "Donald Trump has said Sir Keir Starmer and Emmanuel Macron 'haven't done anything'…", "Mr Trump told a Fox News podcast…", and further statements in the Q&A session. Thus, the entity is actively making statements in the article.
reasoning.candidate_evaluation: Candidate Q22686 (Donald Trump, US President) perfectly aligns with the name, title, and description. Candidate Q3713655 (Donald Trump Jr.) is a different person, Q27947481 is a physician unrelated to the political context, and Q23000825 is a child. Therefore, Q22686 is the sole viable match.
reasoning.authority_verification: Q22686 holds the position of President of the United States, giving him full authority to make the political statements quoted in the article.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: The statements are political in nature, directly related to U.S. foreign policy, and attributed to the sitting president. This is highly plausible and consistent with the role of the US President.
reasoning.final_justification: The target entity is present in the article, is making statements, and the only candidate that matches the name, description, and current position is Q22686. Therefore, this Wikidata ID is the correct attribution for both presence and statement attribution.

speaker_type.explanation: The article explicitly identifies Donald Trump as the US president and quotes him, confirming both his name and the description.

classification_outcome.explanation: The article explicitly identifies Donald Trump as the US president and quotes him, confirming both his name and the description.

reasoning.contradiction_analysis: No contradictions were found between the article’s depiction of Pat McFadden and the Wikidata profile. The article’s context (UK politics, cabinet minister) matches the Wikidata description.

reasoning.identity_verification_and_presence: The article explicitly names "Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky" and later refers to him as "Mr Zelensky". This matches the Wikidata entity’s name (Volodymyr Zelenskyy) and description (President of Ukraine). The spelling difference (single vs double 'y') is a common transliteration variation and does not indicate a different person. No other individual with a similar name is described in a conflicting role, so the identity match is strong.
reasoning.statement_assessment: The article reports that "The Ukrainian president had claimed Mr Trump was living in a Russian 'disinformation space'". This is a reported statement attributed to Zelensky, though not directly quoted. No other direct quotes from Zelensky appear, but the article does attribute a claim to him, indicating he is making a statement.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is entirely plausible for the Ukrainian president to make such a claim about the U.S. president, especially in the context of the ongoing conflict and diplomatic tensions. The statement aligns with the political context described.
reasoning.contradiction_analysis: No contradictions are found between the article’s depiction of Zelensky and the Wikidata profile. The roles, titles, and national affiliation all match.

reasoning.authority_verification: Q27916194 holds the appropriate authority as a former National Security Advisor and current Ukraine envoy, making it credible to make the statements attributed.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for a retired general serving as Trump’s Ukraine envoy to praise Zelensky and discuss their meetings, consistent with the role and context.
reasoning.final_justification: Q27916194 satisfies all critical identification and attribution criteria: name, military/diplomatic background, and the specific role of Ukraine envoy. The entity is present and making statements, so this Wikidata ID is the correct match.

No other individual with a similar name is mentioned, and the context (French president, discussions with Donald Trump) aligns perfectly with the Wikidata profile.

How can you then be credible in the face of China if you're weak in the face of Putin?" These are clear statements attributed to him.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for the French president to make such remarks about the U.S. president’s stance toward Russia, given his role and the diplomatic context described. The statements are consistent with the political positions expected of a head of state.
reasoning.contradiction_analysis: No contradictions are found between the article’s depiction of Macron and the Wikidata entity. The identity and statements are coherent.
